TopicTitle: Insertion dV totally not making sense

Articles.Content:
I've used two different version of transfer window planners; Alex Moon's web-based on, and the in-game Transfer Window Planner addon.

For both versions, I have no issue with the ejection parameters, and they give me correct encounters with the target body. However, the Insertion dV values seem to be totally off.

For example:

http://alexmoon.github.io/ksp/#/Kerbin/250/Moho/100/false/ballistic/true/2/344

This says I can get into a 100km orbit with 3421 m/s. In game I can't even get a capture for less than 3950 m/s (retrograde)! 

If there is some combination of retrograde/normal/radial, it's also not making any sense to me.

Thoughts/suggestions?

Moho is a very special case of interplanetary transfers. Basically it's high inclination and elliptical orbit mean that traditional transfer windows are almost useless. 

Instead, try the method laid out here. 

After reading through that, if you have questions about a specific part, I or someone else will hopefully be able to answer.

I use that too. Here I cropped the other stuff out.

Thats what you need to pay attention to. The transfer window planner works great, and I've done quite a few Mun-Minmus transfers with it, but remember: it assumes a perfect transfer, perfect optional midcourse plane change, and perfect capture. In the game, from things like shaking from gimbal and imperfect SAS, the capture will not be perfect. You should probably bring a little extra Delta-V. 

BTW 4,880 m/s total? That's a pretty Moho transfer! The one I'm preparing for is 5,032 m/s.

Okay, let's take a look at the launch window planner.

This says that if you're in a 250km circular orbit with 0 degrees of inclination you should be able to create a maneuver node 129 degrees from Kerbin's retrograde vector (clockwise) along your orbit with a prograde element totaling 1426.6 m/s and a normal element totaling 298.6m/s.  The total magnitude of the burn will be 1457m/s and you should perform the burn sometime around 3 in the morning of day 345 in year 2 (the time is not exact, you can stray by an orbit or three).  Now, if you can set that up perfectly, as stated, you should have a pretty good chance of an encounter showing up.  That being said, it does sound a bit optimistic for a Moho ejection burn, but you are at a fairly high altitude.

Chances are, though, that you're not in a perfectly circular orbit and your inclination is off by a bit so you might end up adjusting the maneuver node, which is fine.  There's a reason I pack 5.5km/s just to get to Moho.  Plus, the figures assumes a perfect, split-second impulse which you probably won't be able to impart to your ship which means it's going to be off on the accuracy.  Again, that's fine, and also why you pack an extra margin of fuel.

Getting to Moho however, isn't the hardest part, it's the braking burn that's murderous and that's been true ever since I started playing.  Moho is travelling very fast around Kerbol so you've got to bring down your Kerbol-relative apoapsis to match Moho's.  There's no real way around it.  I mean, sure, you can sling around Eve and stuff, but for direct Hohmann transfers you should expect this sort of thing.  Take my advice and pack 5.5km/s both ways.  You may have extra, but you won't regret it.

Edited April 9, 2016 by regex

26 minutes ago, regex said:

Okay, let's take a look at the launch window planner.

 

This says that if you're in a 250km circular orbit with 0 degrees of inclination you should be able to create a maneuver node 129 degrees from Kerbin's retrograde vector (clockwise) along your orbit with a prograde element totaling 1426.6 m/s and a normal element totaling 298.6m/s.  The total magnitude of the burn will be 1457m/s and you should perform the burn sometime around 3 in the morning of day 345 in year 2 (the time is not exact, you can stray by an orbit or three).  Now, if you can set that up perfectly, as stated, you should have a pretty good chance of an encounter showing up.  That being said, it does sound a bit optimistic for a Moho ejection burn, but you are at a fairly high altitude.

Yeah. That worked; I got to Moho without issue on that burn.

 

Quote

Getting to Moho however, isn't the hardest part, it's the braking burn that's murderous and that's been true ever since I started playing. ....  Take my advice and pack 5.5km/s both ways.

Ugh. And I want to land, too. Ok, back to the drawing board...

The alex moon planner tool is great - and it does show how very thin the margins are for Moho transfers. Miss the transfer by a few m/s (changing your intercept position and date) and it can get very expensive very quickly.

TBH, with such a large incoming angle (17.26° !), I'm surprised it was "only" giving 3400 m/s...
